title: Working with custom transcriptomes using factR2
text: Many eukaryotic genes undergo alternative splicing produce multiple RNA isoforms, thus expanding coding regulatory potential genome. transcriptome specific biological samples constructed high throughput sequencing experiments mapping short long reads reference genome assembling alignments transcript architectures. resulting Gene Transfer Format (GTF) files describe newly identified transcripts sets exonic coordinates, contain information coding sequences (CDSs; also known ORFs) possible biological functions transcripts. previously published {factR}, R package construction CDSs novel RNA isoforms. {factR} also predicts domain organisation protein products isoforms, identifies transcripts susceptible nonsense-mediated decay (NMD; pathway destabilizing mRNAs premature translation termination codons). new version {factR}, called {factR2}, extends functionality predecessor adding tools probe regulatory potential alternative exons enhances user-friendliness adopting R object class. {factR2} pinpoints alternative splicing events trigger NMD, tests regulation correlating exon splicing inclusion gene expression level. Additional features {factR2} include direct quantification exonic sequence conservation scores, interactive visualisation transcript domain architectures two-way plot expression exon splicing levels.

title: Working with custom transcriptomes using factR2
text: {factR2} currently available GitHub can installed using {devtools}:
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("f-hamidlab/factR2")

title: Working with custom transcriptomes using factR2
text: {factR2} requires custom transcriptome file GTF format input. file typically generated short-read assemblers StringTie2 (Kovaka et al. 2019) Cufflinks, (Trapnell et al. 2012) long-read aligners minimap2 (Li 2018) Isoquant (Prjibelski et al. 2023). provide sample custom transcriptome file assembled PacBio HiFi data using Isoquant can used test {factR2} functionalities (see ‚ÄúCreating factRObject‚Äù details). Several {factR2} functions require reference genomic sequences transcript annotations. make easy users obtain files, provide convenient system retrieve reference files common model organisms GENCODE Ensembl databases. Users may optionally use reference files inputs.

title: Working with custom transcriptomes using factR2
text: following packages required perform workflow:
code: library(factR2) library(tidyverse)

title: Working with custom transcriptomes using factR2

title: Working with custom transcriptomes using factR2
text: {factR2} comes wrapper functions access information stored within factRObject. preview object‚Äôs contents can printed typing variable name: Transcripts contain distinct sets internal exons defined ‚Äúnovel‚Äù. Note sample GTF lack coding sequence information thus, none transcripts currently annotated ‚Äúcoding‚Äù. metadata genes, transcripts exons segregated individual ‚Äúset‚Äù data factRObject. One ‚Äúset‚Äù data assigned active ‚Äúset‚Äù users may switch active ‚Äúset‚Äù using activeSet() function: exact names ‚Äúset‚Äù can printed using listSets(): metadata associated current active ‚Äúset‚Äù can displayed dataframe using features() function: show columns R dataframe, set show_more argument TRUE: display transcripts expressed particular gene, users can provide IDs names genes input second argument features(). example, query transcripts U2af1 gene, can type: Multiple genes can displayed providing additional gene names: quickly display metadata different ‚Äúset‚Äù, users may modify set argument: use convenient wrapper functions (see ?factR-meta ): alternative splicing event assigned internal unique ID easy referencing can found column ‚ÄúAS_id‚Äù. features() function similar assessor functions outputs dataframe can saved new variable wrangling. Alternatively, output dataframe can directly piped downstream functions. example , show quickly count number events splicing type (AStype): {factR2} pre-built functions visualise transcript architectures interactive plot: Exon structures may sometimes appear thin inconspicuous especially flanking introns extremely long. focus exon architectures, users may set rescale_introns argument TRUE:

title: Working with custom transcriptomes using factR2
text: {factR2} contains 5 key functions probe biological function custom transcripts: buildCDS(): construct CDS information getAAsequence(): translate amino acid sequences predictNMD(): predict NMD-sensitive transcripts testASNMDevents(): pinpoint splicing events leading NMD getAScons(): quantify exon-level sequence conservation scores functions can simultaneously performed running runfactR() pipeline update metadata stored within factRObject: number newly-identified coding transcripts now reflected object summary: Coding transcripts predicted NMD-sensitive now annotated ‚Äúyes‚Äù column ‚Äúnmd‚Äù transcript metadata: total number NMD-sensitive transcripts can queried : Now, plotTranscripts() distinguish CDS untranslated region (UTR) segments: default, runfactR pipeline compute sequence conservation scores entire exon. determine conservation intronic sequences flanking alternative exons (50 base pairs side), users may rerun getAScons() function newly-computed scores reflected separate column ‚Äú‚Äù set metadata:

what: Testing regulatory function of AS-NMD events
title: Working with custom transcriptomes using factR2
text: -NMD events classified ‚ÄúStimulating‚Äù longer form (exon inclusion) transcript NMD-sensitive ‚ÄúRepressing‚Äù shorter form (exon skipping) transcript NMD-sensitive. -NMD event types detected U2af1 example: can visually verified running plotTranscripts() coordinates input: test regulatory function -NMD events, can correlate exon inclusion levels (PSI Percent Spliced ) -NMD events gene expression level. {factR2} can compute gene expression counts PSI values transcript-level expression count matrices. demonstrate , provide sample transcript count matrix detected isoforms postnatal mouse brain two developmental timepoints. count matrix can added factRObject using addTxCounts() function: Users may choose use pre-computed PSI values splicing quantification tool providing path PSI matrix psi argument. test correlation exon PSI values gene expression levels, users may use testGeneCorr() function. default, function perform two-sided Pearson‚Äôs product moment correlation variance-stabilised PSI normalised gene expression expression. Users may customise parameters correlation test parsing addition arguments R cor.test() function. example , show one modify testGeneCorr() function carry one-sided test: function creates 2 new columns metadata: gene.cor.estimate returns correlation coefficient test gene.cor.pval returns unadjusted significant level. -NMD events type ‚ÄúStimulating‚Äù, PSI values transformed 1-PSI correlation coefficient values gene.cor.estimate positive. example , -NMD stimulating event AS10419 showed significant correlation U2af gene expression. can plot two-way plot U2af1 expression AS10419 PSI values using plot2way() function:
code: ase(fobj, "U2af1", show_more = TRUE) #>           AS_id               gene_id gene_name                   coord AStype #> AS10417 AS10417 ENSMUSG00000061613.14     U2af1 chr17:31870620-31870686     CE #> AS10419 AS10419 ENSMUSG00000061613.14     U2af1 chr17:31871476-31871542     CE #> AS10421 AS10421 ENSMUSG00000061613.14     U2af1 chr17:31873953-31874040     CE #>         strand width novel   ASNMDtype ASNMD.in.cds Cons.exon.pad0 #> AS10417      -    67    no        <NA>           NA              1 #> AS10419      -    67    no Stimulating         TRUE              1 #> AS10421      -    88    no  Repressing         TRUE              1 #>         Cons.flanks.pad50 #> AS10417             1.000 #> AS10419             1.000 #> AS10421             0.653 plotTranscripts(fobj, "chr17:31870294-31873065") counts <- system.file("extdata/pb_expression.tsv.gz", package = "factR2") fobj <- addTxCounts(fobj, counts) #> ü°Ü  Adding expression data #>     ‚Ñπ Importing from local file #> ü°Ü  Creating samples metadata #> ü°Ü  Processing expression data #>     ‚Ñπ Adding gene counts #>     ‚Ñπ Adding spliced-event counts #>     ‚Ñπ Normalizing counts fobj <- testGeneCorr(fobj, alternative="greater") #> ü°Ü  Running correlation on 48188 events ase(fobj, "U2af1", show_more = TRUE) #>           AS_id               gene_id gene_name                   coord AStype #> AS10417 AS10417 ENSMUSG00000061613.14     U2af1 chr17:31870620-31870686     CE #> AS10419 AS10419 ENSMUSG00000061613.14     U2af1 chr17:31871476-31871542     CE #> AS10421 AS10421 ENSMUSG00000061613.14     U2af1 chr17:31873953-31874040     CE #>         strand width novel   ASNMDtype ASNMD.in.cds Cons.exon.pad0 #> AS10417      -    67    no        <NA>           NA              1 #> AS10419      -    67    no Stimulating         TRUE              1 #> AS10421      -    88    no  Repressing         TRUE              1 #>         Cons.flanks.pad50 gene.cor.estimate gene.cor.pval #> AS10417             1.000       0.813098344  0.0006501011 #> AS10419             1.000       0.834649627  0.0003661430 #> AS10421             0.653      -0.001520686  0.5018711510 plot2way(fobj, x="AS10419", y="U2af1", plot_trend=TRUE)

title: Working with custom transcriptomes using factR2
text: factR2 can also inspect domain structure protein products encoded newly identified mRNA isoforms using predictDomains() function. function requires connection online PFAM database may require substantial amount time stable internet connection query multiple transcripts simultaneously. quickly explore visualise output predictDomains() tool, user may prefer use plotDomains() function. example, following predict domain structure transcripts U2af1 gene:  want predict domains new transcripts mind waiting time depending connection speed PFAM server load, run following:
code: plotDomains(fobj, "U2af1") fobj <- predictDomains(fobj)

title: Working with custom transcriptomes using factR2
text: factRObject can saved RDS file restored later analysis: Key data stored factRObject (updated GTF file metadata files) can exported text files local workding directory using exportAll function: Alternatively, users may use exportGTF() exportTable() functions export individual data:
code: saveRDS(fobj, "factRObject.rds") exportAll(fobj) exportGTF(fobj) exportTable(fobj, data = "transcript")  # data can be "gene", "transcript" or "AS"

title: Functional Annotation of Custom Transcriptomes v2
text: factR2 represents substantial improvement factR, providing users powerful user-friendly tools work custom-assembled transcriptomes. factR2‚Äôs latest features: Extracts alternative splicing events annotate novelity contribution NMD outcome Tests regulatory potential -NMD events Quantifies evolutionary conservation scores alternative exons Interactive plot transcript architectures well following features factR: Matches gene information custom transcriptomes reference annotation Constructs transcript coding (CDS) information using reference-guided approach Predicts sensitivity coding transcripts nonsense-mediated decay (NMD) Predicts protein domains productively spliced transcripts

title: Functional Annotation of Custom Transcriptomes v2
text: development version can installed using devtools:
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("f-hamidlab/factR2")

title: Construct factR object class ‚Äî createfactRObject
code: createfactRObject(   gtf,   reference,   use_own_annotation = NULL,   use_own_genome = NULL,   project_name = "factRProject",   genome_build = "auto",   match_genes = TRUE,   countData = NULL,   sampleData = NULL,   psi = NULL,   verbose = TRUE )

title: Construct factR object class ‚Äî createfactRObject
text: gtf Either path custom transcriptome file (GTF) GenomicRanges object containing GTF transcriptome data reference Character value ID genome used reference. See listSupportedGenomes() print list supported genomes. Input can also name species (Homo sapiens Hsapiens Human). use_own_annotation Can one following: Path local transcriptome file GenomicRanges object containing GTF transcriptome data AnnotationHub data ID [AHxxxxx] URL GTF file use_own_genome Can one following: Path local FASTA file Biostrings object containing full genome sequence AnnotationHub data ID [AHxxxxx] URL FASTA file project_name Character value name project genome_build Character value genome build. determined automatically default. match_genes Boolean value whether genes custom transcriptome matched reference (Default: TRUE) countData (Optional) Matrix transcript-level counts data sampleData (Optional) Dataframe containing sample metadata psi (Optional) Matrix exon inclusion data data verbose Boolean value whether messages printed (Default: TRUE)

what: NMD predictions at transcript and exon levels ‚Äî factR-NMD
title: NMD predictions at transcript and exon levels ‚Äî factR-NMD
text: Nonsense-mediated decay RNA surveillance mechanism clears transcripts harboring premature stop codon. transcripts can products alternative splicing events (-NMD) ultimately serve post-transcriptional gene regulation mechanism. functions annotates transcripts factRObject sensitivity NMD, based canonical exon-junction model. Protein-coding transcripts containing premature stop codon >50bp upstream last exon junction annotated NMD-sensitive. Sequentially, `testASNMDevents` function pinpoint alternative splicing events lead NMD. -NMD events categorised "stimulating" "repressing". "Stimulating" events trigger NMD upon splicing "repressing" events trigger NMD upon exon skipping.

title: NMD predictions at transcript and exon levels ‚Äî factR-NMD
code: # S4 method for factR predictNMD(object, NMD_threshold = 50, verbose = FALSE)  # S4 method for factR testASNMDevents(object, verbose = FALSE)

title: NMD predictions at transcript and exon levels ‚Äî factR-NMD
text: object factRObject NMD_threshold Minimum distance PTC downstream exon-exon junction trigger NMD (Default: 50) verbose Whether print messages (Default: FALSE)

title: NMD predictions at transcript and exon levels ‚Äî factR-NMD
text: factRObject updated metadata `predictNMD`, 4 additional variables added transcript metadata: nmd: "yes" "" value whether transcript NMD-sensitive stop_to_lastEJ: Integer distance first stop codon  last exon-junction. Positive values indicate stop codon  upstream EJ negative values indicate stop codon  downstrea EJ num_of_downEJs: Number EJs downstream first stop codon 3'UTR_length: Length 3'UTR `testASNMDevents`, 2 additional variables added metadata: ASNMDtype: Type -NMD event. Can "Repressing" skipping  exon leads NMD "Stimulating" splicing exon leads  NMD ASNMD..cds: Whether event found within CDS UTR

title: NMD predictions at transcript and exon levels ‚Äî factR-NMD
code: ## Load sample factR object and predict CDS segments data(factRsample) factRsample <- buildCDS(factRsample)  ## Predict transcript-level NMD sensitivities factRsample <- predictNMD(factRsample)  ## Annotate NMD-causing splicing events factRsample <- testASNMDevents(factRsample)

text: object factR object countData Can one following: Path local count matrix file .tsv .csv format Matrix object containing transcript-level expression counts data. sampleData (Optional) Dataframe containing samples information. Dataframe rows can named match sample names `countData`. `sampleData` row names, function attempt pick column containing sample names assign rownames. psi (Optional) Exon-level splicing inclusion data. Can one following: Path local file .tsv .csv format Matrix object Rownames matrix chr:start-end format verbose Boolean value whether messages printed (Default: TRUE) vst whether apply variance stabilization splicing expression levels min_n minimum number non-NA samples required correlation testing ... additional arguments parsed cor.test function

title: Run factR workflow ‚Äî runfactR
text: wrapper function perform core factR workflow includes: 1:  Building CDS structures 2:  Predicting NMD-sensitive transcripts 3:  Translating open-reading frames 4:  Quantify sequence conservation alternative exons

title: Run factR workflow ‚Äî runfactR
code: runfactR(   object,   NMD_threshold = 50,   cons_db = "phastCons",   cons_type = "exon",   cons_padding = 0,   verbose = TRUE )

title: Run factR workflow ‚Äî runfactR
text: object factR object NMD_threshold Minimum distance PTC downstream exon-exon junction trigger NMD (Default: 50) cons_db Database extract sequence conservation. Can "phastCons" (Default) "phylop" cons_type Feature quantify conservation. Can one following: "exon" : Sequence conservation entire exon "flanks" : Conservation sequences flanking exons "upstream" : Conservation sequences upstream exons "downstream" : Conservation sequences downstream exons cons_padding Additional width pad sequence . cons_type "exons" "flanks", paddings added sides. verbose Whether show pipeline messages (Default: TRUE)

title: Run factR workflow ‚Äî runfactR
text: Update factRObject additional data runfactR. See links detailed description function wrapper.

title: Run factR workflow ‚Äî runfactR
code: ## Load sample factRObject data(factRsample)  ## Run factR pipeline factRsample <- runfactR(factRsample) #> ü°Ü  Building CDS information #>     Searching for reference mRNAs in query #>     22 reference mRNAs found and its CDS were assigned #>     Building database of annotated ATG codons #>     Selecting best ATG start codon for remaining transcripts and determining open-reading frame #>     61 new CDSs constructed #>  #>     Summary: Out of 155 transcripts in `gtf`, #>     83 transcript CDSs were built #>     ‚Ñπ Updating transcript feature data #> ü°Ü  Running transcript-level NMD prediction #>     Predicting NMD sensitivities for 83 mRNAs #>     ‚Ñπ Updating transcript feature data #> ü°Ü  Translating amino acid sequences #>     ‚ùó 1 CDSs do not begin with ATG #>     ‚ùó 2 CDSs contain internal stop codon. Truncating CDS sequence to retain ORF #> ü°Ü  Running AS-NMD testing #>     ‚Ñπ Getting best reference for AS-NMD testing #>     ‚Ñπ Testing AS-NMD exons #>     ‚Ñπ Updating AS feature data #> ü°Ü  Quantifiying conservation scores #>     ‚Ñπ Retrieving phastCons60way.UCSC.mm10 scores #>     ‚Ñπ Quantifying `exon` conservation scores with 0 padding

title: factRObject Class ‚Äî factRObject-class
text: container storing processing custom transcriptome.

title: factRObject Class ‚Äî factRObject-class
text: factRObject representation custom-assembled transcriptome data. Coordinate metadata information input transcriptome (GTF) parsed grouped 3 data Sets corresponds levels gene (genes), transcript (txs) alternative splicing (ase). aid compatible reference genome expression data, functional comparative analyses can performed better understand complexity transcriptome.

title: factRObject Class ‚Äî factRObject-class
text: factRObject can easily constructed : createfactRObject(gtf, reference)

title: factRObject Class ‚Äî factRObject-class
text: Interact factRObject (x) following ways:  summary(x): Prints preview factRObject  head(x): Prints first 6 metadata entries active Set  tail(x): Prints last 6 metadata entries active Set  dim(x): Prints dimension active set (features x samples)  nrow(x): Returns number features active set  ncol(x): Returns number samples factRObject consists 3 `Sets` data: gene, transcript . one time, one `Sets` made active Set factR2 functions called active Set. ways check change active Set:  listSets(x): Lists Sets object  activeSet(x): Returns active Set object  activeSet(x)<-: Change active Set `Set` factRObject hold rich information features contains. convenient wrappers display metadata `Set`.  features(x): Displays metadata active Set  genes(x) gns(x): Displays gene metadata  transcripts(x) txs(x): Displays transcript metadata  ase(x): Displays alternative splicing events metadata factR2 also contain functions plot exon-level domain-level structures interactive plot:  plotTranscripts(x, "gene interest"): Plots transcripts  plotDomains(x, "gene interest")): Plots domains transcript-level counts data provided, additional accessors available:  counts(x): View/extract counts data  samples(x)): Prints sample metadata  rowNames(x)): Print feature names current Set  colNames(x)): Prints sample names  colNames(x))<-: Set new sample names  ident(x)): Prints default sample identity  ident(x))<-: Set new sample identity

title: Quantify feature conservation ‚Äî getAScons,factR-method
text: object factR object db Database extract sequence conservation. Can "phastCons" (Default) "phylop" type Feature quantify conservation. Can one following: "exon" : Sequence conservation entire exon "flanks" : Conservation sequences flanking exons "upstream" : Conservation sequences upstream exons "downstream" : Conservation sequences downstream exons padding Additional width pad sequence . cons_type "exons" "flanks", padding added sides.

title: Quantify feature conservation ‚Äî getAScons,factR-method
text: factRObject additional columns metadata. name column(s) created "Cons.<type>.pad<padding>"

title: Quantify feature conservation ‚Äî getAScons,factR-method
text: default, function quantifies sequence conservation entire exon together 50 base-pair flanking sequence using phastCons database. Alternatively, function can also quantify mean conservation scores sequences flanking exons, sequences upstream/downstream alternative exons. `padding` argument different meaning depending `type` input. `type` "exon", `padding` refers amount intronic sequences sides exon include quantification. `type` "flanks", "upstream" "downstream", `padding` refers amount intronic sequnce
